item.title: Base Metals Slip Amid Dollar Strength
item.description: Base metals prices pulled back as weak demand and dollar strength pressured industrial goods, while gold was higher as the fighting in Israel and Palestine boosted its safe-haven appeal.

item.title: Natural Gas Continues Rise Over Israel Supply Worries
item.description: Natural gas prices continued pushing higher, rising another 5% on worries over supply in Israel.

item.title: Oil Pares Gains Though Upside Risks Remain
item.description: Oil futures were lower in a likely technical correction after settling more than 4% higher on Monday on worries over the situation in Israel and Palestine.

item.title: Fed Speeches Could Send Dollar in Either Direction
item.description: Upcoming speeches by Fed officials on Tuesday could influence the dollar “in one way or the other,” Swissquote Bank said, as the currency started the day marginally higher.

item.title: Eurozone Bond Yields Move Little, Safe Havens Remain Supported
item.description: Eurozone government bond yields were little changed and the risk sentiment picture should become clearer as U.S. markets resume activity after the Columbus Day holiday, UniCredit Research said.

item.title: Huawei Supplier Stocks Jump on Robust Product Demand
item.description: Robust demand for Huawei products is fueling investor interest in the shares of its suppliers, which have bucked declines in the broader mainland Chinese equities market.

item.title: U.K. Retail Sales Growth Slows
item.description: U.K. retail sales for the five weeks to September 30 increased by 2.7%, slowing from the previous month, despite a drop in inflation, as the high cost of living continued to pressure households’ budgets.

item.title: Oil prices and defense stocks climbed after the worst attack on Israel in decades shook financial markets. Major indexes rose, with the S&P 500 and Dow both gaining 0.6% and the Nasdaq adding 0.4%.
item.description: Oil prices and defense stocks climbed after the worst attack on Israel in decades shook financial markets. Major indexes rose, with the S&P 500 and Dow both gaining 0.6% and the Nasdaq adding 0.4%.

item.title: CNN Chief Executive Mark Thompson told staff that the network needs to step up its digital game, saying conventional TV "can no longer define us," and that its journalists shouldn't be distracted by debates about balance or false equivalency.
item.description: CNN Chief Executive Mark Thompson told staff that the network needs to step up its digital game, saying conventional TV “can no longer define us,” and that its journalists shouldn’t be distracted by debates about balance or false equivalency.

item.title: Nearly 4,000 members of the United Auto Workers went on strike at Volvo Group's Mack Trucks unit after rejecting a five-year contract proposal.
item.description: Nearly 4,000 members of the United Auto Workers went on strike at Volvo Group’s Mack Trucks unit after rejecting a five-year contract proposal.

item.title: Country Garden failed to make an international debt payment after the Chinese developer's apartment shares plunged in September, succumbing to a liquidity crisis that worsened over the past few months.
item.description: Country Garden failed to make an international debt payment after the Chinese developer’s apartment shares plunged in September, succumbing to a liquidity crisis that worsened over the past few months.

item.title: Chinese consumers spent and traveled less during the eight-day holiday that ended Friday than the government had projected, figures showed, while home sales in key cities were weaker than last year.
item.description: Chinese consumers spent and traveled less during the eight-day holiday that ended Friday than the government had projected, figures showed, while home sales in key cities were weaker than last year.

item.title: China Evergrande's 11th-hour cancellation of a restructuring affecting more than $19 billion of its international bonds could lead to a messy collapse and have "a catastrophic effect" on other troubled companies in the property sector, its bond investors said.
item.description: China Evergrande’s 11th-hour cancellation of a restructuring affecting more than $19 billion of its international bonds could lead to a messy collapse and have “a catastrophic effect” on other troubled companies in the property sector, its bond investors said.

item.title: Molson Coors secured a credit-rating upgrade and unveiled a plan for $2 billion in share buybacks, moves that follow rising volumes and cash flow.
item.description: Molson Coors secured a credit-rating upgrade and unveiled a plan for $2 billion in share buybacks, moves that follow rising volumes and cash flow.

item.title: Nikkei Rises 2.4%, Led by Energy, Defense Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended higher, led by gains in energy and defense stocks, as Hamas’s attack on Israel led to sharp gains in crude-oil prices.

item.title: Canadian Auto Workers Strike General Motors
item.description: Canadian auto workers went on strike against General Motors after the carmaker failed to reach a temporary agreement by the deadline.

item.title: What's News: Business & Finance
item.description: What’s News: Business & Finance

item.title: Israel Launches Barrage of Attacks on Gaza
item.description: Israel prepared for what could be an extended ground assault, and the Pentagon warned Iran and Hezbollah to “think twice” before joining the conflict.

item.title: How America's EV Ambitions Could Affect the Future of the UAW
item.description: UAW union members have been striking over job security and pay as automakers push forward in developing EV’s, which require fewer workers and cost more in raw materials. So what does that mean for the future of auto workers and the union?

item.title: How High Yields Brought Stocks Down, in 8 Charts
item.description: A surge in bond yields has interrupted the 2023 stock rally, leaving investors sifting through market signals to predict what comes next.
